data.text: Snapped MSR Hubba Hubba Tent Pole: How to Fix

Snapped MSR Hubba Hubba pole. At a bit of a loss to know what to do with this and can't really continue until it's fixed. Because it's snapped at the end, I don't think putting a thin metal sleeve over the end (even if I could get it over the plug thing) will really work. Any ideas?
Sleeve it and use a small hose clamp on the end piece?
data.author: Brian Stewart

data.text: thanks Brian. I used a hose clamp initially when it was just split, but that caused it to snap completely above where the clamp was. The trouble with this pole design is you can't slide a sleeve into place.
data.author: Stephen Tunstall

data.text: you could split the sleeve vertically and clamshell. Or you could cut the bungee and slide the sleeve over.
data.author: Brian Stewart

data.text: The plug comes out easily. Just untie it. Then sleeve it. It‚Äôll be fine.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Sleeve and gorilla tape
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: I had the same on a big agnes, at the hub. I removed the busted piece, jammed the end onto the hub, put a bunch of duct tape on it and kept on hiking and camping for 10 days.
data.author: Chris Hennessey

data.text: Hard to see. Does the red anodized pole slide onto the silver post, or is the post an insert that is supposed to be fixed to the end of the pole? You could try taking the pole apart and cutting the broken end to make the end flat again. Then put it back together. The pole will be an inch or so shorter, but it‚Äôll see you through til you can get the pole section replaced.
data.author: Ben Beardmore

data.text: the red slides over the silver bit
data.author: Stephen Tunstall

data.text: . That should make it easier to just trim the uneven edge so it will sit flush with the hub, and carry on with a slightly shorter pole.
data.author: Ben Beardmore

data.text: in a pinch you can remove the broken bit of pole and wrap a bit of tape around the end to reinforce it since it doesn‚Äôt look too uneven. You might not need to cut it flush at all. MSR has great warranty service. You may be able to get them to send you a replacement section of pole for pick up at a post office along your route.
data.author: Ben Beardmore

data.text: this is what I have done and it works so I have just left it like that
data.author: Kenny Moyer

data.text: I had the same issues many years ago and I wouldn‚Äôt recommend that. I was really hard first to trim the broken edge in a clean way. Second, it‚Äôs almost imperceptible but there is also a thickness difference where it goes over connections, making it strong enough to bend. If you remove the broken inch it ends up breaking more and more. Eventually what had worked for me was to simply remove the broken section by untightening the shock cord etc. Then mounting it again. I then went on with my trip with a slacking saggy tent. I contacted msr and got a free spare section of the frame üòä
data.author: Gildwen Lf

data.text: Try fiber glass with boat resin and gorilla tape with a thin flat metal wrapped around see if it works
data.author: Nico Padilla

data.text: If you untie the bungee and completely remove the pole, you‚Äôll be able to get the sleeve on. Rotate the ‚Äòbroken end‚Äô so the sleeve is fitting over the connection between two poles, and gives you a clean end needed. Bottom line - it‚Äôs a ‚Äúdo what you need until you can get a replacement‚Äù. Don‚Äôt just look at what you need, but what you *have* available to you - think outside the box. Good luck.
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: I did this on both Hubba Hubba & big Agnes tents.. works fine, still have the fixes in place..
data.author: Amanda Heapy

data.text: Cut the broken section off leaving a shorter pole. It‚Äôll work as a temporary fix
data.author: Nick Fortyfive

data.text: I once forgot to pack my poles entirely, but was able to successfully stake the foot of the tent and and then use whatever ropes I had to suspend the upper half of the tent to tree branches.Ôøº
data.author: Roy Brubaker

data.text: Replacement pole on Amazon

data.text: brilliance4u. there are a ton others

data.text: this is what I got to replace my fiberglass ones
data.author: Justin Merrill

data.text: Sleeve & duct tape/zip ties Sleeve can be splint like sticks. Etc
data.author: Preston Paige Piper

data.text: I successfully used the barrel of a pen with the ends cut off slid over as a splint and wrapped on with duct tape to fix a pole I broke at the start of a 6 week tour a couple of years ago. Worth a try üòä
data.author: Sue Wigmore

data.text: I cracked a pole on my Hubba Hubba and contacted MSR. We talked on the phone and they ended up sending me a replacement pole plus new shock cord. Very easy and friendly to deal with.
data.author: Steve Shikaze

data.text: Lots of good ideas here. Also I wonder if the sections on the brow pole are the same length? You could swap sections with the brow pole as the brow is not as vital.
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: Ferropre two part putty
data.author: Jimmy Dee

data.text: The sleeve will definitely fix it temporarily. You'll need to untie the Bungie if this is between connectors in order to get it on. Then slide it over everything and duct tape it. MSR warranties their poles, but you'll need to send it in.
data.author: Timothy Faust

data.text: Small wood dowel. Lots of duct tape. First aid splint.
data.author: Larry LaFavor

data.text: Get some electrical tape and just wrap it up real thick until you can get it fixed. If there are any outdoor stores or camp stores nearby, they may have spare tent poles sitting around. This happened to me and I used electrical tape to kind of hold everything together until I was able to make it to an outdoor gear store. They replaced the broken one with a spare they had.
data.author: Aspen Gentry

data.text: Sleeve
data.author: Kizil Ay Dunord

data.text: Happened to me, sleeve it. Worse case rubber and hose clamps.
data.author: Mark Jessel

data.text: Hubba Hubba is not very study... A friend of mine broke his tent just because it was windy... I recommend going for MSR Elixir. It's a bit heavier, but reliable. When they want to save weight, they cut on material... when you cut too much, things brake.
data.author: Jo√´l Desjardins

data.text: funnily enough I'm in a hostel and there's another cycle tourist here with a broken Elixir pole üòÇ
data.author: Stephen Tunstall

data.text: bad design
data.author: Phil Smith

data.text: Cut up a coke can and wrap it around as many times as you can. Then hose clamps all over it. Or some other kind of attachment method, like fibafix tape, fiberglass cloth and resin, lots of tape and zip ties. Just put some kind of rigid sleeve over it and some kind of clamping force to keep it on. That'll at least be a decent temp fix until you can replace it or fix it properly.
data.author: Timm Lond

data.text: Contact msr, they will ship you the peice that's broken for free/very cheap.
data.author: Luca Wright

data.text: I saw there were kits to repair this. Basically, two halves of a splint that goes over the cracked parts. Maybe that's something you can mcguyver in the field. Maybe a scrap of another discarded pole and duct tape, telephone handset cord or something.
data.author: Erich Tornado

data.text: Medical gauze or any thin fabric coated over with 2 part epoxy (mix well) and rolled over it will act like fibre glass.
data.author: Chris Tan

data.text: Get a soda can, trim and split, wrap and tape.
data.author: Steve Larese

data.text: check out the brains on Steve
data.author: Ken Murphy

data.text: Sierra Designs once overnighted a new pole to us. It was sent to a dealer in the town we were near. Worth calling them or finding the nearest MSR dealer.
data.author: Richard Krebs James

data.text: unfortunately I'm in Bosnia and the nearest is a long way away!
data.author: Stephen Tunstall

data.text: I‚Äôve broken a poles. I sent it in and they replaced it for free.
data.author: Cory Mandt

data.text: My MSR pole. Much better than yours. I had to put the can lid around it and taped it. It worked but it would not survive any strong wind.
data.author: Beggard Beggar
Beggard Beggar

data.text: Thanks for all the responses! Hoping this will hold for a couple of weeks before I can get a replacement part
data.author: Stephen Tunstall

data.text: Well done
data.author: Jim Connelley

data.text: Didn't see you tried this already, this is exactly what I did and it did hold for the remaining of my trip. Just be careful not to damage the tent.
data.author: Vincent Cormi√©

data.text: good looking field repair!
data.author: Gary Zaremsky

data.text: Be careful that the clamps don‚Äôt tear your rain fly. My personal choice would be to replace the clamps with about 3 wraps of duct tape.
data.author: Ben Beardmore

data.text: Piece it back together, wrap it several times with duck tape. Wrap cover that with thin piece from soda can. Wrap another piece of duck tape (mainly to secure the piece of can from moving). Over all of that, cover completely with a strip of heat wrap (warm to melt and sink); slide on first before you start wrapping with tape and can.
data.author: Greg Lozaga

data.text: Lifetime warranty. Until then gorilla tape and leave it in the hub
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: When I replaced the shock cords in my poles I discovered the ends unscrew from the poles. Just do something to keep the cords from sneaking back into the poles. Good luck. If all else fails these folks might be able to help. https://tentpoletechnologies.com/?fbclid=IwAR0w_7DhU6gJu51OsmVQSQIs2voUaaAHnkyM-_12h0oZ5UDcdtFFpw9YvzQ
data.author: Jeffrey Fritts

data.text: I was able to have a broken pole been sent by the chilean importer while I was riding the Carrettera austral. They did it in 3 days. So try to contact msr importer we‚Äôre you are at the moment
data.author: Enrico Chierici

data.text: A friends tent had a pole fail near the end like this - we were able to cut the broken bit off square with a multi tool, and the straps on the tent had enough play to take up the slack and make things taut.
data.author: Paul Lefebvre

data.text:
In FRANCE we can rebuy this part and only this part .....so i am quite sure you can also do it in your country . not expensive . https://www.monbivouac.com/segment-d-arceau-msr-hubba-hubba-nx.html?utm_source=googleshopping&gclid=EAIaIQobChMIsqiZjZmr-AIVbBoGAB3vQwCjEAQYASABEgJSy_D_BwE

data.text: What the hell is that? The repair I mean! Trim off the loose cracked bits, cut/saw/file the long bit square still on the elastic. You have lost what, 1.5cm? your tent will absorb this without issue due to the elastic, job done!
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: I‚Äôm glad I‚Äôm not the only one that saw that!
data.author: Tony Weeks

data.text: that what I was going to say üòâ Get a saw and you‚Äôll see that it‚Äôs quite easy to fix üòú
data.author: V√©ronique Pommier

data.text:
Here's the link for warranty repair ...... https://support.cascadedesigns.com/s/repair-case I don't know how it broke..... Or, your experience with warranty replacement..... Here's how I do it: 1. Name the issue in a sentence. Photos attached. 2. Tell them you're on-tour, and, need an efficient response by email. You'll need to coordinate a shipping address after a decision is made. 3. Explain how the damage happened, how you like the tent, and. If they cannot replace the poles..... What are the options .... Suggestions ... And, offer to pay for the poles if warranty of denied. 4. If you're doing any social media while in tour, include a link to your presence.... Regardless, I've been very pleased with the support I've received..... Especially, on tour. Shipping is more challenging. (I'll use either a hotel address or a warm showers host that I anticipate to pass by in a few days)
Repair Case
support.cascadedesigns.com
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: Context: this is a FAQ from the warranty/repair link above, I searched: Tent Poles Replacement ------- Can I upgrade my Hubba NX Series tent to the Syclone Poles? Yes, Hubba NX, HH NX, MH NX, and PHNX tents are compatible with Easton Syclone poles. If you have one of the following SKUs, produces between 2014-2018, contact our Warranty/Repairs team and they'll be able to help you out with replacements. It will cost you 1/3 the MSRP of a new tent. SKUS: 13067 - HNX Pole Set- Syclone 13069 - HHNX Pole Set- Syclone 13070 - MHNX Pole Set- Syclone 13071 - PHNX Pole Set - Syclone
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: I had the internal bungee go completely slack, and split the end of one segment as a result. I emailed customer service, mailed it in, and they sent a new set. They are fantastic to deal with.
data.author: Tom Nostrant

data.text: Shorten the pole by the broken amount and put the end back on
data.author: Jeff Dove

data.text: yes, post nearest address one of us can check and possibly send you a replacement. It's tough out there and sometimes good to have friends ;)
data.author: Doug Riegner

data.text: Aluminum can and gorilla tape
data.author: Mikey Krome

data.text: Same thing happened to me last summer and I got a replacement part really quickly from MSR. In the meantime I simply used zip-ties and hose clamps. Both worked fine.
data.author: Vincent Cormi√©

data.text: it happened the same to me during a long kayak trip around Sardinia. My tent was a Ferrino Solo, now I see that also MSR can have such problem. Not easy, but I tried inserting a flexible branch inside the poles and wrapping both parts with lot of duct tape. I was at least able to finish the trip and got the whole tent replaced by the producer. Your damage is at the very end though, I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôd work.
data.author: Carlo Parisi

data.text: I sheared two HH poles putting my tent down in the wind. The torn poles ripped through my fly sheet. I sent all back to MSR without any warranty They replaced both poles and fly sheet for free. Incredible service. I only buy MSR kit from here on in. True.
data.author: Simon Jones

data.text: All i can say is this happened to me after probably 2000+ sleeps in the hubba hubba and MSR replaced the whole thing when i sent it to Seattle. But you have to have a USA mailing address for them to send it back to
data.author: Claire Sultan

data.text: Cut it clean, use a file. You are only loosing a couple inches if that. It should work fine. Tent might be a bit less taught that's all...repair or replace when home.
data.author: Eric Morneau

data.text: Not sure it will work with the placing of the break but did your tent not come with a metal repair sleeve?
data.author: Niraj Gohel
Anna Roberts

data.text: Warranty straight away!!
data.author: Oliver Bannister

data.text: Should have a short tube of a bigger ID to slide over that with your tent stakes
data.author: Ronald Jansto

data.text: Short length of pipe cut down it's length. Put it around then close it using pliers. It'll be stronger than the original
data.author: Jimmy Zqueezy Ronin

data.text: Samething happened to me, lucjy there was another Italian cyclist camping where I did. He fixed it with a copper pipe he found in a old geyser. The pipe was wide enough to go over the broken piece.
data.author: Amanda Kruger
